entry.title: Cultivating a Hacker Culture: The Hacker
entry.content:
I’m the type of person who is constantly looking at new technology or ways of developing software. I’m always looking for the next big thing that will allow me to do something I couldn’t before, or do the same stuff quicker or easier. I’ve recently been attracted to watching YouTube presentations on whatever it is that’s on my mind. Recently something got me thinking. Nearly all of the best presentations are given by a class of developers that I associate with being “hackers”.

What’s a “hacker” to me? If you’ve ever seen the movie Hackers (http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113243/), that’s what I’m talking about. A class of developer with a thirst for knowledge and ability. Driven to be “elite” and to have their abilities recognized. Here are a couple examples of some Erlang hackers. The two talks are valuable in general, even if you aren’t interested in Erlang (and if you aren’t interested in Erlang, you probably should be :–)

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mGKMq0Cyiks — Erlang: Noob to production in 2 months http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8BNpOHFvg_Q — Lager: Logging with confidence

One shows how a single hacker developed and deployed a web based chat services to his community in a couple months. The other shows how a developer decided to improve the logging standard that he was forced to work with and by doing so elevated the state of the art for an entire community.

I’ve recently been discussing continuous integration with my co-workers. To most hacker cultures this is simply a given; the first presentation talks about his continuous build/deploy process. He was pimping Erlang’s hot code deployment and “telnet to the VM” capabilities, continuous integration was a given but he briefly discussed his setup.

So where am I going with this? I’ve come to realize that I respect and admire a lot of “hacker” qualities. I want more of that, I want to embody more of that, and I love working with people that have similar aspirations and values.

Up next. The Hacker and The Hacker Culture.
